text: in December of 1972 three astronauts
blasted off on the last Apollo mission
to the moon along the way they looked
back and took these pictures of what
NASA now calls the Blue Marble today
four decades later astronauts look down
at their planet every day from the
International Space Station a tinkertoy
dragonfly orbiting the earth 250 miles
up from here the earth is a world among
other worlds all executing a dance
choreographed by gravity the moon dose
Eidos slowly behind the Earth's limb
squashed flat by the atmosphere sunrise
comes as a sudden arc of light against
black space solar panels shift to catch
the bounty of energy in orbit astronauts
are no longer bound by the cycle of day
and night
some are 'but at a nun setting sun
tracing a wheel in the sky or look down
on the dark shadow of a solar eclipse
by day the earth is alive a single
geological organism you can see it
breathe belching gas from volcanoes and
wrapped by whirling storms of rain and
lightning
the oceans are Earth's glory the source
of its color and life as we know it as
the station slips into night the world's
nervous system emerges
the lonely golf's are lit up by
constellations of oil drilling platforms
extracting the fossilized remains of
ancient Sun fed life the station never
crosses the poles but it goes far enough
north and south to see the wavering
crowns of Aurora once we looked up at
the heavens from Earth now we look down
and out
an Angels view of a spinning ball under
the fixed stars a waypoint for the
wandering comets in the decades since
Apollo robot spacecraft have visited all
the planets except Pluto in July of 2013
the Cassini spacecraft looked back and
snapped a picture far beyond the
many-hued rings of Saturn was our own
Blue Marble pale blue dot as Carl Sagan
called it and still the only pale dot we
know yet
Oh
